text:
After a crazy few months in the spotlight, it should come to no one’s surprise that Kanye West tackles some of his most controversial moments in his latest studio album. “Ye” covers suicide, bipolar disorder, Kim Kardashian-West, and the Tristan Thompson cheating scandal.

Here are some of Kanye’s lyrics, decoded.

I Thought About Killing You

The opening track tackles issue like suicide. The rapper publicly said he had contemplated committing suicide in 2010.

“The most beautiful thoughts are always besides the darkest/Today I seriously thought about killing you/I contemplated, premeditated murder/And I think about killing myself, and I love myself way more than I love you, so.”

Yikes

West references his opioid addiction after getting liposuction and confirms he has bipolar disorder.

“I can feel the spirits all around me/I think Prince and Mike was tryna warn me/They know I got demons all on me.”

“That’s my bipolar s***, n**** what/That’s my superpower, n**** ain’t no disability/I’m a superhero! I’m a superhero!”

All Mine

The star references his sister-in-law Khloe Kardashian and boyfriend Tristan Thompson’s cheating scandal. Thompson cheated on a then pregnant Kardashian, and it turned into a media frenzy.

“All these thots on Christian Mingle/Almost what got Tristan single.”

Wouldn’t Leave

The Kardashians are known for the way they handle themselves publicly. They do major PR damage control, and West references his wife Kim Kardashian-West’s reaction to the comments he made about slavery during a TMZ interview.

“I said, ‘Slavery a choice.’ They say, ‘How, Ye?’/Just imagine if they caught me on a wild day.”

“Wife calling screaming saying we’re about to lose it all/I had to calm her down cause she couldn’t breathe/I told her she could leave me now but she wouldn’t leave.”

No Mistakes

Kanye had to drop out of his Saint Pablo Tour in 2016, and was hospitalized after a psychological breakdown.

“Oh, I got dirt on my name, I got white on my beard/I had dead on my books, it’s been a shaky a** year.”

Violent Crimes

The song writer references his fears about raising daughters, and the way they’ll grow up in our society. He also references one of his favorite movies, Meet the Fockers.

“Don’t do no yoga, don’t do pilates/Just play piano and stick to karate/I pray your body’s draped more like mine and not like your mommy’s”

“Matter of fact Marlin, this ain’t Meet the Fockers/I’ll beat his a**, pray I beat the charges.”
title: Decoding Kanye West’s ‘Ye’ Lyrics
